title: Payment redirection / fake invoice scams (changed bank details)
summary: Scammers send invoices that look real but with changed payment details so your money goes to them.
how_it_works: You receive an invoice that appears to be from a business you used recently.
The bank account/BSB is different from previous invoices.
If you pay, funds go to the scammer.
warning_signs: Email address is close-but-not-exact to the real business.
Pressure to pay fast to avoid penalties or missing a booking.
example_hooks: “Please use our updated bank details for this invoice.”
what_to_do: Call the business using contact details you already know (not the invoice) to confirm payment info.
Use invoice/PO controls if you’re a business.
Report quickly if payment was made to the wrong account.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
